pullRequest.body:
I noticed that `ltByCases` doesn't have any API, and it would be useful to have some when working trichotomously, especially if one wishes to define things trichotomously.

A non-dependent version is also defined.

---

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: For what it's worth, in the context of actually using these, I've found `ltByCases` worthwhile. This is because it calls for things of the form `x < y -> P`, wheras using a `match h : compare x y` construct gives you the requirement to make `P` adding the `h : compare x y = LT` hypothesis, say. But sometimes you want the former, because you then want to define things by cases and thus generalizing `h`: I am not really sure how to do that in term mode! If someone knows, please let me know... but in general I do think this adds utility.

I think this looks good now. After you add the suggested lemma, please feel free to merge this.

bors d+

:v: linesthatinterlace can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7502355733/job/20424835829)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7502355733/job/20424835090)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7502355733/job/20424835597)
What's the point in having a separate definition for the non-dependent case? Did you consider making it an `abbrev` so that at least the lemmas don't have to be repeated?
Also, I would call it `ltTrichotomy` to mirror `lt_trichotomy`.

Well, we do it for ite (this is meant to be the analogy as ite is to dite). Similarly it's sometimes useful to have ergonomic versions of lemmas for that kind of thing? Again, there is precedent for this.
Agreed that ltTrichotomy would be a good name

I have changed it to `ltTrichotomy`,and made it an `abbrev`, but I still think there is a use for the lemmas (notably `simp` can't solve them - you'd have to unfold the definition). And the abbreviation is useful!
I don't think that this lemma and the next two should be `simp`.
I don't have a good notion for when a lemma does or doesn't make a good simp lemma. Though I think I probably agree here, I thought these were a bit iffy.
A lemma is a good `simp` lemma if we (almost) always want to simplify LHS to RHS. In particular, RHS should be simpler than LHS.
Removed, and also for `ltTrichotomy`.

Could you please create a variant of this, that proves
```
ltByCases x y h h h = Q
```
by splitting it into 3 goals `(hlt : x < y)  h hlt = Q`, `(heq : x = y)  h heq = Q`, ...

It can then also be used to slightly golf this congr proof.

I meant something like
```
lemma ltByCases_rec {h : x < y  P} {h : x = y  P} {h : y < x  P} (p : P)
    (hlt : (h : x < y)  h h = p) (heq : (h : x = y)  h h = p) (hgt : (h : y < x)  h h = p) :
    ltByCases x y h h h = p := by
  simp [ltByCases, *]
```
But maybe it's actually not completely trivial to use this to golf the congr lemma.
Huh. I am not quite sure I see the usefulness of that. I'm trying to see how I'd use it in practice.
Well, I have a use case for it (-; I can use this api to cleanup parts of the proof that shows that the nerve of a category is a quasicategory. And this extra lemma would be useful for me there.
Yeah, fair. When I have a mo I'll stick it in.
I added it and also a couple more lemmas (I hope that's OK, they were natural accompaniments).

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Order/Basic): Add `ltByCases` API

But sometimes you want the former, because you then want to define things by cases and thus generalizing `h`: I am not really sure how to do that in term mode!
